author: sdowdy
body:
## Steps to reproduce

```# wget https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/download/v7.0.3/powershell_7.0.3-1.debian.10_amd64.deb
# dpkg -i powershell_7.0.3-1.debian.10_amd64.deb
(Reading database ... 458603 files and directories currently installed.)
Preparing to unpack powershell_7.0.3-1.debian.10_amd64.deb ...
Unpacking powershell (7.0.3-1.debian.10) ...
dpkg: error processing archive powershell_7.0.3-1.debian.10_amd64.deb (--install):
 error creating directory './usr/local/share/man': Read-only file system
Processing triggers for man-db (2.8.5-2) ...
Errors were encountered while processing:
 powershell_7.0.3-1.debian.10_amd64.deb
```

## Expected behavior

package should install

## Actual behavior

package violates Debian pkg policy regarding /usr/local  (both by creating *files* and failing to exit successfully)

https://www.debian.org/doc/debian-policy/ch-opersys.html#site-specific-programs

> As mandated by the FHS, packages must not place any files in /usr/local, either by putting them in the file system archive to be unpacked by dpkg or by manipulating them in their maintainer scripts.

> Since /usr/local can be mounted read-only from a remote server, /usr/local/*/dir/ directories
> must be created and removed by the postinst and prerm maintainer scripts and not be
> included in the .deb archive. These scripts must not fail if either of these operations fail

Here's the files in the package that aren't allowed to be created and should not fail a READONLY condition on /usr/local:
```# dpkg-deb -c powershell_7.0.3-1.debian.10_amd64.deb  | grep /usr/local
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2020-07-15 13:55 ./usr/local/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2020-07-15 13:55 ./usr/local/share/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2020-07-15 13:55 ./usr/local/share/man/
drwxr-xr-x 0/0               0 2020-07-15 13:55 ./usr/local/share/man/man1/
-rw-r--r-- 0/0            1907 2020-07-15 13:55 ./usr/local/share/man/man1/pwsh.1.gz
```

## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

N/A


thanks,
--stephen

comments.body:
On 9/11/20 3:23 PM, Travis Plunk wrote:
> looks like |usr/share/man| is the correct location.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/13517#issuecomment-691317956>, or unsubscribe <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AFNEP7UUJ4JHMRBK7KQAIKTSFKINDANCNFSM4QLBCGWA>.
> 

Well, at least Debian usually defers to the FHS, which specifies:


https://refspecs.linuxfoundation.org/FHS_3.0/fhs/ch03s13.html

   | 3.13. /opt : Add-on application software packages

   |  The directories /opt/bin, /opt/doc, /opt/include, /opt/info, /opt/lib, and /opt/man are reserved for local system administrator use. Packages may provide "front-end" files intended to be placed in (by linking or copying) these   reserved directories by the local system administrator, but must function normally in the absence of these reserved directories.

   |  Programs to be invoked by users must be located in the directory /opt/<package>/bin or under the /opt/<provider> hierarchy. If the package includes UNIX manual pages, they must be located in /opt/<package>/share/man or under the /opt/<provider> hierarchy, and the same substructure as /usr/share/man must be used.


Since you're using /opt/microsoft already, the obvious place would be /opt/microsoft/share/man.

However, it looks like you're packaging a lot of different versions of PS in the package, so there would be collisions on manpages from the variant versions.


$ sudo apt-file list powershell | grep -i -e '\.doc' -e '\.pdf' -e '\.rtf' -e '\.txt'

I'm gonna say, to me, it looks like:

    /opt/microsoft/powershell/7/share/man

might be more appropriate  (but, whatever, in my mind, it should be in /opt/microsoft/....)

I do, however see:
(ins)sdowdy@carrotcake$ sudo apt-file list powershell | grep -v ' /opt/microsoft'
powershell: /usr/bin/pwsh
powershell: /usr/local/share/man/man1/pwsh.1.gz
powershell: /usr/share/doc/powershell/changelog.gz
powershell-lts: /usr/bin/pwsh
powershell-lts: /usr/local/share/man/man1/pwsh.1.gz


you're also affecting standard paths

(ins)sdowdy@carrotcake$ ls -l /usr/bin/pwsh
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 32 Jul 15 13:55 /usr/bin/pwsh -> /opt/microsoft/powershell/7/pwsh*

so, yeah, everything should be in the FHS directories areas (/opt/microsoft).

Anyway, that's up to y'all, i'm just mainly pointing out that i can't install the current packaging in my NFS readonly shared /usr/local/ environment (easily).

thanks,
--stephen

title: powershell .deb violates Debian Policy 9.1.2 (creation of files in /usr/local/ and ignoring readonly failures there)
